The 'epididymis' (; plural: epididymides ) is part of the male reproductive
system and is present in all male amniotes. It is a single, narrow, tightly-
coiled tube (in adult humans, six to seven meters in length {{Cite book
|title=Glenn's urological surgery |last=Kim |first=Howard H. |authorlink=
|last2=Goldstein |first2=Marc |editor1-last=Graham |editor1-first=Sam D. |editor2-
last=Keane |editor2-first=Thomas E. |editor3-last=Glenn |editor3-first=James F.
|editor4-last= |editor4-first= |edition=7th |volume= |year=2010 |origyear=
|page=356 |pages= |chapter=Chapter 53: Anatomy of the epididymis, vas deferens,
and seminal vesicle |publisher=Lippincott Williams & Wilkins |place=Philadelphia
|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=GahMzaKgMKAC&pg=PA357&lpg=PA357&dq=Epidid-
ymis&source=bl&ots=mUWjDHkZvv&sig=s1C1rOEYPitXyyVXPjsG_E2MIxY&hl=en&sa=X&ei=eUI-
HUJHDNePY2AXPuNAC&ved=0CE8Q6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=Epididymis&f=true |accessdate= |isbn=978-0-7817-9141-
0 |oclc= }} ) connecting the efferent ducts from the rear of each testicle
to its vas deferens. A similar, but probably non-homologous, structure is found
in cartilaginous fishes.
headings: Role in storage of sperm and ejaculant
